definition: lit. drink the northwest wind (idiom); cold and hungry
to drink/variant of 嗬[he1]
to shout
west
the West/abbr. for Spain 西班牙[Xi1 ban1 ya2]/Spanish
north/(classical) to be defeated
wind/news/style/custom/manner/CL:陣|阵[zhen4],絲|丝[si1]

sentences.english: I just knew that our sales sucked wind and we were burning through tons of cash.
sentences.chinese: 我只知道公司一边在大量烧钱而另一边却在喝西北风。

sentences.english: The bosses expect their workmen to live on air.
sentences.chinese: 这些老板指望他们的工人喝西北风过日子。

sentences.english: You are not going to stand me up again, are you?
sentences.chinese: 你不会再让我喝西北风吧？

definition: to beg (for food or money)
to have difficulty getting by/to struggle (financially etc)
impossible to make a living
to go hungry/to starve
to pack and quit/to be sacked
to tire oneself out through overwork/to work oneself to death
to live one's life/to make a living
lit. just sitting and eating, one can deplete even a mountain of wealth (idiom)/fig. to spend one's money without generating any income
to starve to death/to be very hungry
lit. to eat delicious food and drink hard liquor (idiom)/fig. to live well
to make a hard living as unskilled laborer
to close down a business for good and put the best face on it (idiom)
to freeload
erhua variant of 幹活|干活[gan4 huo2]
poor
one's utmost/(to fight or work) desperately hard/to put up a life or death struggle/at all costs
